title: The Frick Pittsburgh - Wikipedia
content:
[Jump to content](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Frick_Pittsburgh#bodyContent) [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Wiki_Loves_Monuments_Logo_notext.svg/70px-Wiki_Loves_Monuments_Logo_notext.svg.png)\\ Photograph a historic site, help Wikipedia, and win a prize. Participate in the world's largest photography competition this month!Learn more\\ [Coordinates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system "Geographic coordinate system"): ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/WMA_button2b.png/20px-WMA_button2b.png)[40°26′47″N79°54′09″W﻿ / ﻿40.446350°N 79.902512°W﻿ / 40.446350; -79.902512](https://geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=The_Frick_Pittsburgh¶ms=40.44635_N_79.902512_W_region:US-PA_type:landmark) From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia Museum in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania This article is about the museum in Point Breeze, Pittsburgh. For the museum at the University of Pittsburgh, see [Frick Fine Arts Building](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frick_Fine_Arts_Building "Frick Fine Arts Building"). For the museum in New York City, see [Frick Collection](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frick_Collection "Frick Collection"). | [![The Frick Pittsburgh's logo](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/0/03/The_Frick_Pittsburgh_Logo.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:The_Frick_Pittsburgh_Logo.png)
The Frick Pittsburgh's logo | | [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/TheFrickArtMuseumatClayton.jpg/250px-TheFrickArtMuseumatClayton.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:TheFrickArtMuseumatClayton.jpg)
The Frick Art Museum at the Frick Pittsburgh | | [![The Frick Pittsburgh is located in Pittsburgh](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Pittsburgh_locator_map_2018.png/250px-Pittsburgh_locator_map_2018.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pittsburgh_locator_map_2018.png "The Frick Pittsburgh is located in Pittsburgh")
![The Frick Pittsburgh](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/20px-Red_pog.svg.png)
Location within Pittsburgh | The Frick Pittsburgh **The Frick Pittsburgh** is a cluster of museums and [historical buildings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Historic_house_museum "Historic house museum") located in [Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh,_Pennsylvania "Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania"), United States, and formed around the Frick family's nineteenth-century residence known as "Clayton". It focuses on the interpretation of the life and times of [Henry Clay Frick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Clay_Frick "Henry Clay Frick") (1849–1919), industrialist and art collector. The complex, located on 5.5 acres (22,000 m2)[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Frick_Pittsburgh#cite_note-post-gazette.com-1) of lawn and gardens in the city's [Point Breeze](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Point_Breeze,_Pittsburgh,_Pennsylvania "Point Breeze, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania") neighborhood, includes Clayton, the restored Frick mansion; The Frick Art Museum; The Car and Carriage Museum; the Greenhouse; the Frick [children's playhouse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Children%27s_playhouse "Children's playhouse"); and The Café. The site welcomes over 100,000 visitors a year. Admission is free to the gardens, the permanent collection of the Frick Art Museum, and certain areas of the Car and Carriage Museum, but fees do apply in order to view special exhibitions at both of the museums as well as for tours of Clayton. The property was listed on the [National Register of Historic Places](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Historic_Places "National Register of Historic Places") in 2025. [Helen Clay Frick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helen_Clay_Frick "Helen Clay Frick") (1888–1984) was the driving force to preserve the Frick estate and allow it to open to the public after her death. ## History \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=The_Frick_Pittsburgh&action=edit§ion=1 "Edit section: History")\] [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/FrickMansionClayton.jpg/250px-FrickMansionClayton.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:FrickMansionClayton.jpg) The Frick Mansion "Clayton" Today's museum began as an eleven-room, Italianate-style house purchased by the Fricks shortly after their marriage in 1881. The house was built in the 1860s, original architect unknown. After modifications by Pittsburgh architect Andrew Peebles, it was renamed "Clayton". Further remodeling of the house was done in 1892 by Pittsburgh architect [Frederick J. Osterling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frederick_J._Osterling "Frederick J. Osterling"). The Playhouse was constructed in 1897 to designs by architects [Alden & Harlow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alden_%26_Harlow "Alden & Harlow"). The house served as the Fricks' primary residence from 1883 to 1905. The Fricks moved to New York City in 1905, where they eventually established the [Frick Collection](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frick_Collection "Frick Collection"), but in 1981 daughter Helen Clay Frick returned to Clayton, where she had previously spent part of each year, and remained there permanently until her death in 1984. Clayton opened to the public in 1990, and in 1997 the 1950s carriage house was enlarged to create the Car and Carriage Museum.\[ _[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_\] In May 2013 the center announced a $15 million renovation to break ground on June 6, 2013.[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Frick_Pittsburgh#cite_note-post-gazette.com-1)[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Frick_Pittsburgh#cite_note-CBS_Pittsburgh_2013_v638-2) The renovation was completed in 2015; the Car and Carriage Museum was expanded to twice its original size, and a community center and education center were built.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Frick_Pittsburgh#cite_note-Lyons_2015_q849-3) In May 2025, Clayton was added to the [National Register of Historic Places](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Historic_Places "National Register of Historic Places").[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Frick_Pittsburgh#cite_note-4)[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Frick_Pittsburgh#cite_note-5) ## Collections \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=The_Frick_Pittsburgh&action=edit§ion=2 "Edit section: Collections")\] [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Frick_Car_and_Carriage_Collection.jpg/250px-Frick_Car_and_Carriage_Collection.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Frick_Car_and_Carriage_Collection.jpg) Cars in The Frick's car and carriage museum. The Frick Art Museum's collection includes a large group of works on paper by [Jean-François Millet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean-Fran%C3%A7ois_Millet "Jean-François Millet"), [Renaissance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renaissance "Renaissance") and [Baroque](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baroque "Baroque") bronzes, and nineteenth-century European paintings. There are also Late Medieval and Renaissance paintings of a devotional nature by: Bernardo Daddi, Lippo Memmi, Giovanni di Paolo, Francesco di Vannuccio ("Saint Catherine"), Rainaldo di Rainuccio da Spoleto, Sassetta, Matteo Di Giovanni, Francesco Melzi, and Jean Bellegambe. In the Frick Art Museum, there are Renaissance and Baroque paintings with secular themes by: Apollonio Di Giovanni ("Scenes from [Homer's Odyssey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer%27s_Odyssey "Homer's Odyssey")"), [Jean-Louis de Marne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean-Louis_de_Marne "Jean-Louis de Marne") ("Seine at Saint Cloud"), [Carle Van Loo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carle_Van_Loo "Carle Van Loo"), [Maurice Quentin de la Tour](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maurice_Quentin_de_la_Tour "Maurice Quentin de la Tour"), [Peter Paul Rubens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Paul_Rubens "Peter Paul Rubens"), [Jan Steen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jan_Steen "Jan Steen"), [Jan van Os](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jan_van_Os "Jan van Os"), and [Arthur Devis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthur_Devis_(1712%E2%80%931787) "Arthur Devis (1712–1787)"). In Clayton, in the mansion Frick lived in are 19th Century paintings by Jules Cazin, [Jean-François Raffaëlli](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean-Fran%C3%A7ois_Raffa%C3%ABlli "Jean-François Raffaëlli"), and [Anton Mauve](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anton_Mauve "Anton Mauve").\[ _[original research?](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research "Wikipedia:No original research")_\] Automobiles on display include an 1881 [Brougham](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brougham_(car_body) "Brougham (car body)"), 1898 [Panhard et Levassor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panhard_et_Levassor "Panhard et Levassor") Tonneau, 1903 [Baker Electric](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baker_Electric "Baker Electric"), 1906 Outing Wagon, 1909 [Bailey Electric](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bailey_Electric&action=edit&redlink=1 "Bailey Electric (page does not exist)") Phaeton, 1909 Keystone Sixty-Six Roadster, 1911 [Penn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Penn_(automobile) "Penn (automobile)") 30 Touring Car, 1912 [Daimler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daimler_Company "Daimler Company") [Landaulet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Landaulet_(car) "Landaulet (car)"), 1914 [Ford Model T](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_Model_T "Ford Model T") Touring Car, 1914 [Rolls-Royce Silver Ghost](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rolls-Royce_Silver_Ghost "Rolls-Royce Silver Ghost") Touring Car, 1917 [Standard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard_Motor_Company "Standard Motor Company") Model E Touring Car, 1924 [Auto Red Bug](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Auto_Red_Bug "Auto Red Bug") Flyer, 1931 [Lincoln](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lincoln_(automobile) "Lincoln (automobile)") Model K Sport [Phaeton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phaeton_body "Phaeton body"), and 1940 [American Bantam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Bantam "American Bantam") Convertible Coupe.\[ _[original research?](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research "Wikipedia:No original research")_\] The museum hosts numerous exhibitions. For example, from June 11, 2016 to September 4, 2016, it hosted the visiting exhibition " [Killer Heels: The Art of the High-Heeled Shoe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Killer_Heels "Killer Heels")."[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Frick_Pittsburgh#cite_note-Narrop-6)[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Frick_Pittsburgh#cite_note-Heels-7) ## Selection of works \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=The_Frick_Pittsburgh&action=edit§ion=3 "Edit section: Selection of works")\] - [![Still Life with Fruit, Jan van Os, 1769](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/JanVanOsFruit69.jpg/330px-JanVanOsFruit69.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:JanVanOsFruit69.jpg "Still Life with Fruit, Jan van Os, 1769") _Still Life with Fruit_, [Jan van Os](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jan_van_Os "Jan van Os"), 1769 - [![Chagrin d'Enfant, Emile Friant, 1898](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Chagrind%27EnfantEmileFriant.jpg/250px-Chagrind%27EnfantEmileFriant.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Chagrind%27EnfantEmileFriant.jpg "Chagrin d'Enfant, Emile Friant, 1898") _Chagrin d'Enfant_, [Emile Friant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emile_Friant "Emile Friant"), 1898 - [![Sir Joshua and Family at Roehampton House, Putney, Arthur Devis, 1752](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/ArthurDevisSirJoshuaFamily.jpg/330px-ArthurDevisSirJoshuaFamily.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:ArthurDevisSirJoshuaFamily.jpg "Sir Joshua and Family at Roehampton House, Putney, Arthur Devis, 1752") _Sir Joshua and Family at Roehampton House, Putney_, [Arthur Devis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthur_Devis_(1712%E2%80%931787) "Arthur Devis (1712–1787)"), 1752 - [![Banks of the Seine at Lavacourt, Claude Monet, 1879](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/ClaudeMonetBanksoftheSeine.jpg/500px-ClaudeMonetBanksoftheSeine.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:ClaudeMonetBanksoftheSeine.jpg "Banks of the Seine at Lavacourt, Claude Monet, 1879") _Banks of the Seine at Lavacourt_, [Claude Monet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Claude_Monet "Claude Monet"), 1879 - [![The Arts in Supplication, Carle van Loo, 1764](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/CarleVanLooArtsinSupplication.jpg/330px-CarleVanLooArtsinSupplication.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:CarleVanLooArtsinSupplication.jpg "The Arts in Supplication, Carle van Loo, 1764") _The Arts in Supplication_, [Carle van Loo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carle_van_Loo "Carle van Loo"), 1764 - [![Madonna and Child with Saints, Scenes from Life of Christ and Life of the Virgin, painter unknown, from Master of the Scrovegni Chapel Presbytery, circa 1308](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/FrickArtMuseumScrovegniChapel.jpg/500px-FrickArtMuseumScrovegniChapel.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:FrickArtMuseumScrovegniChapel.jpg "Madonna and Child with Saints, Scenes from Life of Christ and Life of the Virgin, painter unknown, from Master of the Scrovegni Chapel Presbytery, circa 1308") _Madonna and Child with Saints, Scenes from Life of Christ and Life of the Virgin_, painter unknown, from Master of the [Scrovegni Chapel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scrovegni_Chapel "Scrovegni Chapel") Presbytery, circa 1308 -
